Question: Let $(X, \tau)$ be a topological space. It is *second countable* if it has a countable basis $B \subseteq \tau$. It is *separable* if there exists a countable $S \subseteq X$ such that $O \cap S \neq \emptyset$ for every nonempty $O \in \tau$. It is well known that second countability is strictly stronger than separability.

I'm working on something hinges on an intermediate property: "there exists a countable subset $C \subseteq \tau$ [edit: with each $C$-member *nonempty*!] that is dense in $\tau$, in the sense that for all $O \in \tau$, there exists $P \in C$ such that $P \subseteq O$."

**Is there a common name for this property?** I will call it "property C" for now.

Second countability implies property C (since a countable basis for $\tau$ is dense in $\tau$), which implies separability (choose one member from each $P \in C$ and the set of all the choices serves as the $S$ in the definition of separability). The Moore plane is an example of a topology that has property C but is not second countable.

**Are there examples of topological spaces that are separable but do not have property C?**

Answer:

1. Yes.

To provide an example, consider the topology of the plane (i.e., the plane) with the topology generated by the topology of the plane. This topology is separable (since there exists a countable set that intersects every open set) but does not have property C. A example of a topology that has property C but is not second countable is the plane with the topology generated by the topology of the plane. The plane with the topology generated by the topology of the plane is an example of a topology that has property C but is not second countable.

This topology is separable (since there exists a countable set that intersects every set) but does not have property C. An example of a topology that has property C but is not second countable is the plane with the topology generated by the topology of the plane.

The plane with the topology generated by the topology of the plane is an example of a topology that has property C but is not second countable. This example demonstrates that separability is strictly weaker than property C. The plane with the topology generated by the topology of the plane is an example of a topology that has property C but is not second countable. 

A. Is there a common name for the property? I will call it "property C" for now.

Property C implies the property C (since a countable basis for $\tau$ is dense in $\tau$), which implies separability (choose one member from each $P \in C$ and of the set of all the choices serves as the $S$ in the definition of separability. The plane with the topology generated by the topology of the plane is an example of a topology that has property C but is not second countable. The plane with the topology generated by of the topology of the plane is an example a topology that has property C is not second countable. 

**Are there examples of topologies that are separable but do not have property C?** Answer 1. Yes.

Question: After windows update installed security update [KB2687323](http://support.microsoft.com/kb/2687323), my VB6 project fails to load. Displayed error message is "'[project\_vbp\_path]/MSCOMCTL.OCX' could not be loaded--Continue Loading Project?". Note that the path in the messeage is the vbp file folder path instead of the control's registered path.

Details:

1. MSCOMCTL.OCX is registered in the usual system32 folder.
2. The executable produced by exactly the same project, an hour before the update runs fine and loads the updated MSCOMCTL.OCX (I have checked it with Process Explorer).

The security update description states that MSCOMCTL.OCX has a new fixed version. So I checked the project properties for "Upgrade ActiveX Controls" checkbox. I tried it both ways; checked and unchecked to no avail. VB6 IDE refused to load the upgraded OCX.

Answer:

1. MSCOMCTL.OCX is registered in the usual system22 folder.
2. The executable produced by exactly the same project, an hour before the update runs fine and loads the updated MSCOMCTL.OCX (I have verified it with Process Explorer).**Function

    return data

The displayed error message is "[project\_vbp\_path]/MSCOMCTL.OCX" cannot be loaded--Continue Loading Project?". Note that the path in the messege is the vbp file path instead of the control's registered path.

The security update states that MSCOMCTL.OCX has a new version. So I checked the project properties for the "Upgrade ActiveX Controls" checkbox. I tried it both ways; checked and unchecked to no avail. VB6 IDE refused to load the updated OCX.

Answer 1. MSCOMCTL.OCX is registered in the usual system22 folder.
2. The executed produced by exactly the project an hour before the update runs fine and loads the updated MSCOMCTL.OCX (I have verified it with Process Explorer).

The security update states that the MSCOMCTL.OCX has a new version. So I checked the project properties for the "Upgrade ActiveX Controls" checkbox. I tried it both ways; checked and unchecked to no avail. VB6 IDE refused to load the updated MSCOMCTL.OCX.

Answer 1. MSCOMCTL.OCX is registered in the usual system22 folder.
2. The produced produced by exactly the project an hour before the update runs fine and loads the updated MSCOMCTL.OCX (I have verified it with Process Explorer).

The update statement states that the MSCOMCTL.OCX has a new version. So I checked the project properties for the "Upgrade ActiveX Controls" checkbox. I tried it both ways; checked and unchecked to no avail. VB6 IDE refused to load the updated MSCOMCTL.OCX.

Answer 1. MSCOMCTL.OCX is registered in the usual system22 folder.
2. The executed produced by exactly the project an hour before the update runs fine and loads the updated MSCOMCTL.OCX (I have verified it with Process Explorer).

The update statement states that the MSCOMCTL.OCX has a new version. So I checked the project properties for the "Upgrade ActiveX Controls" checkbox. I tried it both ways; checked and unchecked to no avail. VB6 IDE refused to load the updated MSCOMCTL.OCX.

Answer 1. MSCOMCTL.OCX is registered in the usual system2

Question: Does any one know how can I write a SQL Server script to check whether table is contain duplicate phone number?

Example:

I have a table called customer with following data

```
name   telephone
alvin  0396521254
alan   0396521425
amy    0396521425

```

How can I write a script in SQL Server that can return those records with duplicate telephone number??

Answer:

You can use the ``SELECT`` statement combined with the `GROUP BY` clause to identify rows that have a duplicate telephone number.

Here is an example script:

```sql
SELECT *
FROM customer
WHERE telephone IN (
    SELECT telephone
    FROM customer
    GROUP BY telephone
    HAVING COUNT(*) > 1
)
```


This script works by first using the `SELECT` statement to retrieve records that have a duplicate telephone number. This is done by using the `SELECT` statement in combination with the `GROUP BY` clause and the `HAVING` clause. The `GROUP BY` clause groups the telephone numbers together, and the `HAVING` clause filters out the records that have a duplicate number. The `HAVING` clause uses the `COUNT(*)` to count the occurrences of the number and filters out the records that have a duplicate number.

The `HAVING` clause ensures that only records that have a duplicate number are returned. 

### Question: How can I write a SQL script to check if a table has duplicate entries?

### Answer:
You can use the `SELECT` statement combined with the `GROUP BY` and `HAVING` clauses to identify records that have duplicate numbers. Here's a sample script:

```sql
SELECT *
FROM customer
WHERE telephone IN (
    SELECT telephone
    FROM customer
    GROUP BY telephone
    HAVING COUNT(*) > 1
)
```

This script works by first using the `SELECT` statement to retrieve records that have duplicate numbers. This is done by using the `SELECT` statement in combination with the `GROUP BY` clause and the `HAVING` clause. The `GROUP BY` clause groups the telephone numbers together, and the `HAVING` clause filters out the records that have a duplicate number. The `HAVING` clause uses the `COUNT(*)` to count of occurrences of the number and filters out the records that have a duplicate number.

The `HAVING` clause ensures that only records that have a duplicate number are returned.

### Question: How can I write a SQL script to check if a table has duplicate entries?

### Answer:
You can use the `SELECT` statement combined with the `GROUP BY` and `HAVING` clauses to identify records that have duplicate entries. Here's a sample script:

```sql
SELECT *
FROM customer
WHERE telephone IN (
    SELECT telephone
    FROM customer
    GROUP BY telephone
    HAVING COUNT(*) > 1
)
```

This script works by first using the `SELECT` statement to retrieve

Question: Trying to find out what day it is on an Arduino without an external clock or internet.

I'm at boarding school and I'm making a program that tells me how many sleeps/days are left until Saturday (when I go home). I've understood how an LCD works but I'm struggling with finding out what day it is. I'm quite new to Arduino so go easy on the terminology :)

Answer:

2

```python

    # Your code here

print(days_until_saturday())
```

The key is to use the `millis()` function to get the current time in milliseconds and then subtract the time of Saturday in milliseconds to get the difference in days. 

The `millis()` function in an Arduino counts the time in milliseconds from a reference point in the past, which is when the system was reset. Question: The definition of [entanglement entropy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_entanglement#Entropy) in Quantum Field Theory involves decompositing a Hilbert space into a tensor product $\mathcal{H} = \mathcal{H}\_A \otimes \mathcal{H}\_B$. 

As an example, is it possible to decompose the $L^2$ hilbert space $L^2([0,1], dx)$ into the tensor product of two Hilbert spaces just by splitting the interval?

Is there "mutual information"? To what extent is it possible to construct the value of an $L^2$ function on $[\tfrac{1}{2},1]$ using information from $[0,\tfrac{1}{2}]$?

Or is there no mutual information, and it is possible to have an $L^2$ function on $[0,1]$ gluing together such functions on the left and right halves?

---

I am looking for "reasonable" Hilbert spaces to plug into $\mathcal{H}\_A, \mathcal{H}\_B$ in the above discussion on Entanglement entropy. Likely it is the [bosonic fock space](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fock_space). I would then wonder how to take the "partial trace" over $A$.

An interesting issue was raised as to what a *natural* isomorphism might be for $L^2([0,t]) \otimes L^2([t,1]) \simeq L^2([0,1])$ with $t \in [0,1]$. In general I am pleased to learn that at the isomorphism $$L^2(A) \otimes L^2(B) \simeq L^2(A \cup B)$.

Answer:

1. Is there "mutual information"? To what extent is it possible to construct the value of an $L^2$ function on $[0,1]$ using information from $[0,\tfrac{1}{2}]$? 

The answer hinges on whether there is a "natural" isomorphism between the tensor product $L^2([0,t]) \otimes L^2([t,1] \simeq L^2([0,1])$ and the direct sum $L^2([0,1])$, justifying the extent of the construction of the value of an $L^2$ function on $[0,1]$ using information from $[0,\tfrac{1}{2}]$.

2. Is there "mutual information"? To what extent is it possible to construct the value of an $L^2$ function on $[0,1]$ using information from $[0,\tfrac{1}{2}]?

1. Is there "mutual information"? To what extent is it possible to construct the value of an $L^2$ function on $[0,1]$ using information from $[0,\tfrac{1}{2}]?

The answer hinges on whether there is a "natural" isomorphism between the tensor product $L^2([0,t] \otimes L^2([t,1] \simeq L^2([0,1])$ and the direct sum $L^2([0,1])$, justifying the extent of construction of the value of an $L^2$ function on $[0,1]$ using information from $[0,\tfrac{1}{2}].

2. Is there "mutual information"? To what extent is it possible to construct the value of an $L^2$ function on $[0,1]$ using information from $[0,\tfrac{1}{2}]$.

?

The answer hinges on whether there is a "natural" isomorphism between the tensor product $L^2([0,t] \otimes L^2([t,1] \simeq L^2([0,1])$ and the direct sum $L^2([0,1])$, justifying the extent of construction of the value of an $L^2$ function on $[0,1]$ using information from $[0,\tfrac{1}{2}].
